title: I have a judgement on an actor, may I send a wage/residual garnishment to Paramount Pictures to collect my judgement?
question: Or do I need to send a writ of execution to do this.
answers:
I agree with the others in that the actor is probably not an at-will employee of Paramount. You will likely have better fortune at collecting against the actor by garnishing bank accounts or looking for other assets to seize. Enforcement of a judgment can be tricky but there are some powerful tools that give the law real teeth here. Speak to an attorney who is experienced at collection of judgments.

I think it's unlikely that an actor is actually employed by Paramount, but you could try.

While I cannot give you legal advice in this forum, if the amount is significant, you should consider getting a collections attorney to do this for you. They will probably take 1/3 of what is collected but it is much more efficient that trying to do this yourself. For garnishments/levies the paperwork needs to be perfect to avoid issues.
I doubt the actor is an "employee" of Paramount (if they are, a garnishment is correct). If they are owed money for services that are not "wages," then you'd send a levy for non-earnings money owed.
